title: How To Overcome Emotional Eating
summary: You can start by creating a daily meal ritual that helps you to break the cycle of emotional eating and put you in a better mindset for making healthier food choices. Eating quickly can increase feelings of hunger and overeating, plus it’s associated with an increased risk of developing cardiovascular diseases. Eating more fibre can help to reduce hunger, improve digestive issues and reduce feelings of anxiety and make it more likely to turn to food again when you’re not hungry. Eating slowly can help you to savour your food, be more mindful and help prevent overeating.

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Understand The Root Cause Of Your Emotional Eating"),mdx("p",null,"Before you can start to break your emotional eating habits, it\u2019s important to take time to understand the root cause behind your emotional eating. The following questions can help you gain a better understanding of why you eat when you\u2019re feeling stressed or anxious. By reflecting on the positives and negatives of your current emotional eating habits, you can start to develop eating strategies that are more in line with your health and happiness goals."),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"What situations regularly trigger you to turn to food?"),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"What do you typically eat during these situations?"),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"What emotions do you feel when you\u2019re eating?"),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"What emotions do you feel when you\u2019re not eating?"),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"What emotions would you like to feel in those situations instead?")),mdx("h2",null,"Create A Meal Ritual"),mdx("p",null,"Part of overcoming emotional eating is learning how to take control of your eating habits. You can start by creating a daily meal ritual that helps you to break the cycle of emotional eating and put you in a better mindset for making healthier food choices. Try a few of these tips as part of your meal ritual to help you break the emotional eating cycle."),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Eat breakfast: It\u2019s a common belief that skipping breakfast is a good way to lose weight. In fact, research suggests that people who regularly eat breakfast are more successful at maintaining a healthy weight than those who don\u2019t. So make sure to include a healthy breakfast in your meal ritual to kick start your day with a healthy eating kick-start."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Take your time: Eating quickly can increase feelings of hunger and overeating, plus it\u2019s associated with an increased risk of developing cardiovascular diseases. Try to be mindful of the quality of your eating ritual by taking your time to truly savour each bite."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Switch off from work: Many of us eat at our desks as we try to fit our daily meal rituals around our work schedules. What we may not realise is that eating while we\u2019re distracted by work can make us more likely to overeat and less likely to make healthy eating choices."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Be social: When you\u2019re fully absorbed in your work, it can be easy to ignore your body\u2019s hunger and satiety cues leading to overeating. Plus, research suggests that people who eat with others are less likely to be influenced by emotions such as stress."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Be mindful: Eating is a very common activity but it\u2019s also one that, by its very nature, is often done on autopilot. Practise mindfulness during your meal ritual by savouring each bite of your food, becoming fully aware of your body and the emotions that may be influencing you at the time.")),mdx("h2",null,"Develop Healthy Eating Habits"),mdx("p",null,"As well as creating healthy eating rituals, you can also start to develop healthy eating habits that can help to break the cycle of emotional eating. Try using the following tips to help you develop healthier eating habits that can help prevent emotional eating."),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Choose a healthy go-to snack: It\u2019s important to have a healthy snack option on hand for times when you\u2019re feeling hungry. However, it\u2019s important to choose a healthy option that won\u2019t cause you to overeat or sabotage your diet in other ways. Try a handful of nuts, a bowl of mixed seeds, an apple with peanut butter, a smoothie made with a protein shake, or a low-fat yoghurt with granola."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Drink plenty of water: Although it\u2019s commonly suggested that drinking water can help to reduce cravings, it can also help to reduce feelings of hunger and prevent overeating. Try to drink a healthy amount of water throughout the day to help you stay hydrated, feel fuller for longer and prevent emotional eating."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Eat slowly: Eating more slowly can help you to savour your food, be more mindful and help prevent overeating. Try eating each meal more slowly, allowing yourself to fully chew your food and appreciate its flavour and texture."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Eat more fibre: Eating more fibre can help to reduce feelings of hunger, improve digestive health and reduce feelings of anxiety. Try to eat more fibre-rich foods such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts and seeds."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},"Avoid eating when you\u2019re stressed: It may be a common recommendation but it\u2019s also an important one. Eating when you\u2019re stressed can cause digestive health issues, increase feelings of anxiety and make it more likely that you\u2019ll turn to food again when you\u2019re not truly hungry.")),mdx("h2",null,"Practise Self-Care Strategies"),mdx("p",null,"Another important part of overcoming emotional eating is learning how to practice self-care strategies that help you to better manage your emotions. Try to build self-care into your daily routine to help you to take better care of yourself and your mental health. This can include things like taking more frequent breaks from work, meditating, yoga, spending more time in nature, getting enough sleep, and spending more time with friends and loved ones."),mdx("p",null,"Try to also focus on developing positive coping strategies to help you deal with negative emotions as they arise. This can include things like journaling, talking to a friend, or doing a creative activity to help you to release your emotions and better manage your mental health."),mdx("h2",null,"Commit To Fitness Activities"),mdx("p",null,"Exercising is commonly recommended as a way to help treat a range of conditions from depression and anxiety to eating disorders. Not only can regular exercise help to improve your mental health, but it can also help you to lose weight and better manage your eating habits. When you regularly exercise, you\u2019re likely to eat less as you\u2019re more likely to feel full after smaller portions. Plus, exercise has been linked to improved emotional well-being and reduced feelings of anxiety and depression."),mdx("p",null,"Try to commit to a regular fitness routine to help you improve your mental health and reduce your emotional eating. What type of exercise you do and how often you do it will depend on your fitness level. But the important thing is to commit to regular exercise to help boost your mental health and help you to overcome emotional eating."),mdx("h2",null,"Take Care Of Your Mental Health"),mdx("p",null,"Alongside trying to reduce your emotional eating, it\u2019s also important to take care of your mental health. When you\u2019re regularly experiencing negative emotions, it can be easy to turn to unhealthy coping mechanisms such as emotional eating. However, it\u2019s important to tackle the root cause of your negative emotions to truly overcome them. This can include things like practising mindfulness, reaching out to loved ones, and seeking professional help."),mdx("p",null,"When you\u2019re regularly experiencing negative emotions, it can help to keep a journal to track your moods and see if there are any patterns behind them. This can help you to identify what triggers your negative emotions and help you to better manage them. It can also help you to come up with coping strategies that are more effective than emotional eating."),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"An emotional eater is someone who regularly overeats in response to stress, anxiety, or other negative emotions. You can start to break your emotional eating habits by creating healthy meal rituals, developing healthier eating habits, practising self-care, and committing to fitness activities. You can also take care of your mental health to prevent emotional eating. By following these tips, you can break your emotional eating habits and feel better about yourself."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Your Home a Haven

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Creating a home is something that we all strive to achieve. For most, this is somewhere to relax and unwind after a hard day\u2019s work. It also needs to be somewhere that feels safe, somewhere where we can shut out the troubles of the world and just be ourselves. Creating a home is no easy feat though, especially when you consider all the things you need to consider from furnishing, decorating and creating spaces that feel like ours. That being said, creating your perfect home doesn\u2019t have to be as difficult as it sounds. There are plenty of ways in which you can make your home your own personal haven. Below are some tips on how you can transform your home into your very own haven..."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Benefits of Regular Exercise - And How to Get Started

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Getting into a regular workout routine is something that\u2019s a lot easier said than done for most people. While some of us have it easier than others when it comes to fitting fitness into our busy lives, we all struggle with different things at one point or another. It\u2019s easy to let other responsibilities fall by the wayside and not get moving, so you need to be strategic about how and when you work out. While there are many different benefits to exercise, the biggest thing that it has to offer is stress reduction. If you\u2019re looking for ways to reduce your stress in your everyday life, adding exercise to your routine is a great place to start. Here are some reasons why getting your sweat on regularly could be exactly what you need right now:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Get Fit without a Gym Membership

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In today\u2019s fast-paced society, most of us struggle to find time to exercise. While it\u2019s easy to overlook the benefits of exercising when you have a packed day, staying active can have a positive impact on your life. The American Council on Exercise states that being active has been proven as beneficial for mental and physical health as well as quality of life. The following are 5 ways to get fit without a gym membership.
With the rise in popularity of home gyms and personal training, more people than ever before are getting fit without stepping foot into a gym. In this article, we explore five ways you can get fit without joining a gym or purchasing an expensive home setup. Whether you have a small apartment or live in an area with limited outdoor activities, there are many different ways you can stay active and get fit without spending money on a gym membership or personal trainer.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Easy Ways to Cut Sugar from Your Diet

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In recent years, sugar has received a lot of negative attention. From the link between sugar and obesity to the prevalence of diabetes, research on sugar and its potential health effects continues to grow.
There are many different types of sugars out there, but common table sugar or sucrose is the one you need to cut back on. Eating too much sugar can lead to weight gain, high blood pressure and other health problems. If you\u2019ve read any articles about how bad sugar is for you, then you probably already know this. However, cutting back on sugar isn\u2019t always easy. Sugar is in almost everything! Luckily, we\u2019ve compiled a list of 10 super helpful tips that will teach you how to cut back on your intake of this not-so-nice white substance\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Health Benefits of Walking - And How to Get Started

Here are some tips on how you can get started on that walking routine and keep it going..."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Create a Healthy Grocery List on a Budget

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you\u2019re on a tight budget, it can feel like hitting up the grocery store is one of the last things you can afford to do. However, there are ways to make your food dollars go further and still eat well.
Instead of making weekly trips to multiple stores and markets, plan a shopping day and hit one store at a time. Look for sales in that store before you go and stock up on foods that are good value. You might even consider investing in a membership card or becoming an insider or club member so you get vouchers or other discounts. Adding your own spin on some classic cheap meals will also help you save money without sacrificing nutrition. It just takes some planning and research to make it work!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Choices When Eating Out
How to Get through the Work Day When You're Tired

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Fatigue at work can be a real struggle for some people, but luckily there are ways to cope with the challenges of feeling tired at work.
It\u2019s not uncommon for employees to feel exhausted and unmotivated during the work day. Whether you have a long commute, stressful workload or unforgiving managers, being tired at your job is something that many workers deal with on a daily basis.
Unsurprisingly, research shows that when you\u2019re tired at work it has a negative effect on your efficiency and performance. It also makes you more prone to making mistakes and forgetting things.
Fortunately, there are ways to help manage these struggles and get through your work day when you\u2019re tired. Here are some helpful tips that can make all the difference:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Ways to Make Your Commute Less Stressful

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you think about your daily commute, it probably doesn\u2019t strike you as being particularly stressful. In fact, many people see their daily drive to work or school as a time for peace and quiet. After all, what could possibly be stressful about getting from point A to point B?
It\u2019s true that your commute isn\u2019t inherently stressful. In theory, it\u2019s just a short period of time each day when you go from home to work (or vise versa). But even the most seemingly insignificant details can make a big difference. Read on to learn more about how you can reduce stress during your commute and get to work happier every day!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"You\u2019ve probably heard it before: When you\u2019re busy, you need healthy snacks to keep you going. The problem is that it\u2019s not always easy to find healthy snacks that are also fast and convenient. In our hectic, on-the-go world, most of us don\u2019t have time to sit down for a healthy meal three times a day. Instead, we\u2019re often forced to make snap decisions about what we can eat quickly and conveniently. Unfortunately, those decisions too often lead to less than healthy snack options like potato chips or sweets. However, there are plenty of great ways to get your recommended daily intake of fruits and veggies even when you\u2019re on the go. These 30 healthy snacks for on-the-go are perfect for keeping in your purse, desk drawer, locker, or anywhere else you might find yourself hungry and without access to a full meal."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
